To add to the rich story I love how they mixed in religious references throughout.

Lyrics:

Love
bonds of sea and fire
floating in the sea,
travelling across the great distance
even the flames of the war cannot
break the love of those
who found true peace in their soul

I 
want to know where this
love is leading me
through the violence of the great war
I see a new peace
light shines through the dark
abyss of no return
through the ocean and the flames

boyfriend, 
do you hear me?
where are you now?
far away, 
but even death can't separate us 
from each other
that's true love
I saw you 
through the darkness
you dreamt of me
now our arms are crossing
through the distance
I can feel you
a part of me
you're inside me!

snippet.textDisplay:
Xenogears=my favorite game of all time
At first some plot elements are thrown to the player in a confusing way,  but it all makes sense in the end. Xenogears is a story spanning several millennia that involves four different incarnations of the Contact and the Antitype, heroes that actually have flaws and feel human, heartwrenching drama scenes, villains that are just heroes in disguise, visuals that most people criticize but I like more than those of FF7, an absolutely awesome OST, lots of character development not only for Fei, but also for other important characters like Elly, Citan, Bart and even the "big bads" Ramsus, Grahf and Krelian and a heartwrenching ending which is neither happy nor sad (Fei saved Elly and the world, but the destruction of the Zohar prevented Gears and technology from working, so the world is now in a state almost as bleak as how it would have been if Deus had succeeded in absorbing all humans), and I wish that Square Enix made a Xenogears HD remaster for the PS4 with a new battle system, improved visuals and all the cut content being an actual part of the game instead of being explained to us in a 30-minute cutscene or completely omitted, even at the cost of having three discs (The El-Regrs for example: I loved Elly so much and I wish I could play as her in her Omnigear)!
I'm so sad Italian JRPG fans have never seen this masterpiece of a game coming to their country and I wish Square Enix could make another story like this one for FF16, or perhaps rename FF16 the Xenogears HD remaster so that Italian FF fans may play it. Please, Square, remember what you once were and give me a Xenogears HD remaster!

snippet.textDisplay:
Un altro italiano che gioca a Xenogears? Impressionante! Non vedo l'ora di poterne incontrare uno dal vivo (ho un conoscente che si chiama Andrea Setti ed è un gran appassionato di Final Fantasy 7 e 8, ma Xenogears l'ha conosciuto solo grazie a me). Non so perché, ma in Italia dei JRPG se ne sa così poco chedi tutta la mia scuola (non della classe, proprio di tutta la scuola) io sono l'unico che nel 2017 ancora gioca a Final Fantasy 7 e 8, che sono giochi più vecchi di me!
Mi dispiace di essere un 2000 e quindi di essermi perso l'era dei grandi JRPG della PS1 (da me soprannominati anche "romanzi interattivi" per la loro storia e i loro personaggi ben costruiti), però sto recuperando tutti i grandi JRPG di fine anni 90-inizio 2000 e devo ammettere che molti di essi sono tra i miei giochi preferiti. Meno male che sta cominciando una nuova era di JRPG sulla PS4, perché quelli della 1 me li sono persi! Oltre a Xenogears gioco anche a FF7-8, Chrono Trigger (per me fortemente sopravvalutato perché l'ho giocato dopo Xenogears e quindi non sono riuscito ad apprezzarlo come lo apprezzano i fan), Chrono Trigger Crimson Echoes (ci vuole l'emulatore se lo vuoi scaricare, ma è molto meglio di Trigger), Chrono Cross, Final Fantasy Tactics e Suikoden 2. Tu quali JRPG hai?

snippet.textDisplay: I honestly think this is the most amazing melody ever written. I have been trying to figure out what makes it so brilliant, that initial flute melody. It's on a pentatonic scale of the first 5 notes of the A major scale but the bass sits on E and it all actually suggests E dorian given the c-sharp, backed up by the bass using the tonic, subdominant and dominant of E, but nowhere in the melody or the backing is the third of E minor used, so it all hints at E dorian while never confirming it, hovering round that magical I - IV chord progression that the dorian mode has, kind of permanently pushing at it, and it all just hovers between two scales like a dream. It consumes me.

snippet.textDisplay: It was largely incomplete, the Game. The book details everything that the developers wanted to incorporate but couldn't due to their fund being siphoned to another project. (I forget which Final Fantasy took precedent, It was either 8 or 9.) That being said, even with it's hastened work towards the end of Disk One and the entire of Disk 2 the game itself is emotional. The characters and their struggles, their growth and their personal demons that they need to overcome. While some get a smaller demon to face (In relation to Rico and Billy) Others have long term and much more character defining ones. Maria, Citan, Fei, Bart and Elly.

snippet.textDisplay: I was about to write about how awesome the game is, but in the end the comment from @Emad sums it best. The game is such an impressive combination of jaw-dropping and original stuff that it's extremely hard to find something else that even come comes close to it. Of course it's a stretch to say it's the best game ever, but this would be true for anything and any game. A book has been published after the game came out, titled Xenogears: Perfect Works, which explain a lot of the universe the designers had created for the game. This alone gives a feeling of how well thought-out the game has been. Personally, the perfect combination of the thought-provoking and mature story, plot, narrative and music are what creates this killer game. On top of that, you have mechas, plenty of wtf and epic moments, anime-style art and cutscenes, world map, non-linear exploration (jumping), two different types of battles, two minigames... they don't do games like this anymore.

snippet.textDisplay:
I do recall a semi-lucid dream or two I had where my creative faculties felt markedly more potent than they were in waking life. For a talented and well-educated musician to be able to produce whole works while dreaming seems very plausible. 

I'd actually wager it's a fairly common occurrence. I guess one of the biggest challenges would be in managing to retain the melody and notation as your brainwaves accelerate and your waking consciousness takes precedence. It does seem to have a certain ethereal quality about it.

snippet.textDisplay:
Xenosaga was a reimagining of Xenogears, and in fact there are a good number of similarities and links between them, despite their timelines and universes being separate.

Xenoblade was a separate title altogether - originally called 'Monado', but later renamed in an homage/allusion to the Xenoverse. I think it is the realisation of Takahashi's desire to create a game for a younger audience, in addition to a crystallisation of his knowledge and experiences as to what makes a good 'game'. But I think reading between the lines, he was disappointed that there doesn't seem to be much of a mass market for more complex, personal games like the prior two.

snippet.textDisplay:
+Chris Theo apples and oranges, neither Xenosaga nor Xenoblade can be considered spiritual sequels to this masterpiece in any way. Perhaps the title made you think of them? the only thing they have in common is the director and that they all have a sci-fi setting, but alas that is where the similiarities end. 

Most of the key staff that worked with him at square either stayed or moved on to other projects. I get that these games have a cult following around the world, but I feel that Xenogears does not have match in the JRPG world in terms of story. Gameplaywise is another story though, I wish they would have all kept the chrono trigger gameplay intact.
snippet.textOriginal:
+Chris Theo apples and oranges, neither Xenosaga nor Xenoblade can be considered spiritual sequels to this masterpiece in any way. Most of the key staff that worked with him at square either stayed or moved on to other projects. I get that these games have a cult following around the world, but I feel that Xenogears does not have match in the JRPG world in terms of story. Gameplaywise is another story though, I wish they would have all kept the chrono trigger gameplay intact.

snippet.textDisplay:
@Minnan1 Looking back, Xenogears feels like the next step from Chrono Trigger in some ways. Chrono Trigger was revolutionary for that brief moment in time and Xenogears took many of the attributes that made CT so great and then evolved the battle system and story beyond what any other console game had attempted. 


The fact that Yasunori Mitsuda composed the soundtrack might be the biggest reason why I loved this game so much. He got his first chance at Squaresoft to compose the soundtrack for Chrono Trigger and really blew gamers away with the music he wrote for Xenogears. Most of us didn't realize it at the time, but the music score Mitsuda wrote was the driving force behind the strong feelings and nostalgia we feel for Xenogears.
snippet.textOriginal:
@Minnan1 Looking back, Xenogears feels like the next step from Chrono Trigger in some ways. Chrono Trigger was revolutionary for that brief moment in time and Xenogears took many of the attributes that made CT so great and then evolved the battle system and story beyond what any other console game had attempted. 


The fact that Yasunori Mitsuda composed the soundtrack might be the biggest reason why I loved this game so much. He got his first chance at Squaresoft to compose the soundtrack for Chrono Trigger and really blew gamers away with the music he wrote for Xenogears. Most of us didn't realize it at the time, but the music score Mitsuda wrote was the driving force behind the strong feelings and nostalgia we feel for Xenogears.

snippet.textDisplay:
@jetser24 
It's kinda sad... video game music can be as good as movie soundtracks (it all depends on the composer's talent, really). I remember someone saying that he played Rose of May (from FF9) before his teachers at a conservatory. At first, the teachers were all "It's beautiful." and then this person told them it was from a video game and all of sudden, the teachers began to retract. Some people are clearly fixated on not recognizing VG's artistic value for some dumb reason.

snippet.textDisplay:
Completely agree with Idolores.  The story blew every other RPG in history out of the water, but their budget got too tight.  There are many things wrong with Xenogears, but there are many MORE things right with it.  It stands as the greatest RPG of all time, despite the flaws.

That said, I would be scared of a remake... scared they would try to do more than just upgrade the graphics and fill out the second disc.
snippet.textOriginal:
Completely agree with Idolores.  The story blew every other RPG in history out of the water, but their budget got too tight.  There are many things wrong with Xenogears, but there are many MORE things right with it.  It stands as the greatest RPG of all time, despite the flaws.

That said, I would be scared of a remake... scared they would try to do more than just upgrade the graphics and fill out the second disc.

snippet.textDisplay: Actually, there are no new games at the moment that are just awesome. snippet.textDisplay: i have to say it's one of the only rpgs where i still have to think how best to explain to someone in a brief logline, which certainly says something about the ambition of the people who made it. when i bought it, i bought it with the premature impression that it's just a "game to play until ff7 comes out" (or did it come soon after ff7? i don't quite remember) ironically, i thought that ff7 was truly something special, xenogears will always be above it in my mind.

snippet.textDisplay: You don't sound like a dork. Actually *blushes* when my husband was dating me, he sent me his copy of Xenogears for me to play through. That game was just an experience for me, period. I remember going to school and staring off into space contemplating the philosphies of that game. Even though it's been years since I've played, it's one of the few games that's just stuck with me.

snippet.textDisplay: yes, i've always been a fan of sprites. specifically in chrono trigger, this game of course, secret of mana. i think the appeal of sprites is in its ability to provide nuances but still leave character behavior to your imagination. the fighting poses and choreography in xenogears is pretty damn detailed! and the "victory poses" have a lot of charm because their body language tells a story of who they are (the way elly flips her hair back, or aeris breathes a sigh of relief after a fight)

snippet.textDisplay: hahahaha, you know, i'm a huge fan of this game but i do have to concede that i loved the battle system on foot as well. as far as the gears, i think i managed to overlook just how relatively simplistic it was compared to the sheer joy of customizing your moves on foot (and it's just a heck of a lot more fun if you ask me). while i certainly don't hate it, yeah it would've been interesting to see what else they could've done with it.

snippet.textDisplay: you know what's interesting though. people can say what they want about how xenogears aged in terms of now meaning 2008. but i remember even in something like 1999 or 2000, i've heard some game shop employees complaining about the graphics, which is weird because i never really thought of it as a bad-looking game by any stretch of the imagination back then. in fact, i think the sprites have a lot of charm and i loved the backgrounds as far as artistry is concerned.
